blog_graphql.naslovBlogaHr: Šimićeva hajdučka družina napadala je i pljačkala putnike, ucjenjivala bogatije muslimane, ali i kršćane.
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
At the time when the Turkish Empire was weakening, the poor Christian population in Bosnia and Herzegovina was being oppressed. In the 19th century the imposts and taxes were growing bigger and the ruling Muslim caste grew more ruthless. As resistance to such oppression the number of hajduks grew. At that time that was the only form of resistance against Ottoman Turks in these areas.

The most eminent among the Croatian hajduks was Andrija Šimić, born on 22nd November 1833, in a small village Alagovac, district Ružići, in the western Herzegovina.

Šimić’s hajduk gang attacked and robbed the passengers, blackmailed rich Muslims, but also Christians. When they needed money desperately, they would also rob the poorer passengers. Šimić, known and popular as Hajduk Andrijica, forbid his partners to intercept and rob women. Even though he was a hajduk, he tried to remain moral and pointed out he was a believer. Šimić’s hajduk gang was active in the second half of 1868 and through the entire 1869 in the Turkish territory. At the end of 1869, they moved their activities to Austro-Hungarian Empire. Together with people from Vrlika, they came to Imotska krajina, where in Vinjani near Imotski, they robbed people on their way to a fair in Duvno, on 26th August 1870. This robbery was the final straw and both Austrian and Turkish authorities were mobilized and planning their arrest.

In Zagvozd, on 11th January 1871, the pandurs caught most of the bandit gang, while Šimić managed to escape. While running away he shot the pandur Tomičić. He hid in Podosoje where one night, on 14th January 1871, the locals betrayed him and handed him over to the authorities in Imotski.

After an investigation in Split prison, the trial to hajduks began on 16th June 1872. It lasted 22 days. It is important to mention that this was the first court hearing in Croatian language in Dalmatia. Šimić was sentenced to life imprisonment. During his time in prison in Kopar, he and his relatives filed several pardon applications, but they were all denied. It was only Šimić’s application, which he filed probably at the beginning of May 1901, that was accepted. The emperor pardoned him. Having served 31 years in prison, on 17th December 1901 Andrija Šimić arrived by ship to Split where he was greeted by a heap of delighted people on the Split waterfront.

According to popular folk tales, namely, Andrijica used to buy off the Ottoman’s land in order to build houses for people in Vinica, giving them horses and cows, which was the main reason they liked him in Dalmatian Zagora and Herzegovina, despite his criminal past. It was not surprising therefore, that he had a spectacular reception in Split.

Everyone wanted to see the living legend that day.

In villages he was treated as a living legend, and people of Sinj made him their guest for seven days, proclaiming him even an honorary member of the Sinj Alka. It was on that occasion that this photograph was made where Andrijica proudly poses for the photographer. In 1905 he died and is buried in the village Runovići.

It is without any doubt that the charisma and glory of this hajduk played a great part when choosing the name of the Split’s football club Hajduk. One of the most interesting descriptions of Andrijica is written by Ivan Mimica (1862 – 1945) who wrote 3616 decasyllables while serving his punishment with Šimić in the Kopar prison and published them in 1894 in Split as a “Poem in five books on the work of Andrija Šimić”

He wrote:

“I have had the opportunity to meet Andrija Šimić and talk to him on many occasions… Šimić is a short old man, slightly bent towards the mother earth, with a high forehead, clear eye, expressive face and, surprisingly and unusually tough, wiry, alive, talkative and cheerful for his age. He is loved by his elders, and respected and honored by those who don’t love him. He gives good advice to everyone, turns everyone away from the evil and helps whenever he can. He knows cures for many diseases, knows how to interpret dreams, how to pray to God and many other good and nice things he knows. He just doesn’t know how to swear and knows no evil at all this man, raised among wolfs and hajduks, and carrying himself the hajduk title.”

 

Igor Goleš

U doba slabljenja Turskog Carstva dolazi do ugnjetavanja siromašnog kršćanskog stanovništva u Hercegovini i Bosni. U 19. stoljeću nameti i porezi sve su veći, a vladajuća muslimanska kasta sve bezobzirnija. Kao otpor takvom potlačivanju pojavljuje se hajdučija u sve većem broju. Bio je to jedini oblik otpora protiv Osmanlija na ovom području.

 

Među hrvatskim hajducima ističe se Andrija Šimić koji se rodio 22. studenoga 1833. u zaseoku Alagovac, župa Ružići, u zapadnoj Hercegovini.

Šimićeva hajdučka družina napadala je  i pljačkala putnike, ucjenjivala bogatije muslimane, ali i kršćane. Kada su bili u nuždi, pljačkali bi i siromašnije putnike. Šimić, popularno zvan Hajduk Andrijica, branio je svojim ortacima pretresati ili pljačkati žene. Iako hajduk, on se trudio iskazivati moral i naglašavati da je  vjernik. Njegova hajdučka družina djelovala je u drugoj polovici 1868. i cijelu 1869. godinu na turskom teritoriju. Krajem 1869. aktivnosti prenose i na područje Austro-Ugarske Monarhije. Šimićeva hajdučka družina, udružena s Vrličanima, dolazi u Imotsku krajinu gdje u Vinjanima 26. kolovoza 1870. pljačkaju putnike koji idu na sajam u Duvno. Hvataju imotskog trgovca Dunića i ucjenjuju ga. Nakon ove pljačke kap je prelila čašu pa se  i austrijske i turske vlasti   mobiliziraju te prave plan za njihovo uhićenje.

U Zagvozdu 11. siječnja 1871. panduri hvataju većinu razbojničke družine, dok Šimić uspijeva pobjeći. Pri uzmicanju ubije pandura Tomičića. Sklanja se u Podosoje gdje ga noću 14. siječnja 1871. lokalci izdaju i predaju imotskim vlastima.

Nakon istrage, u splitskom zatvoru počinje suđenje hajducima 16. lipnja 1872. Trajalo je 22 dana. Važno je napomenuti da je ovo bila prva sudska rasprava na hrvatskom jeziku u Dalmaciji. Šimić je osuđen na doživotni zatvor. Tijekom izdržavanja kazne u zatvoru u Kopru on  i njegova rodbina šalju više zamolbi za pomilovanje, ali sve su odbijene. Tek zamolba koju je podnio vjerojatno početkom svibnja 1901. biva uslišana. Car ga pomiluje. I tako Andrija Šimić, nakon 31 godinu uzništva, 17. prosinca 1901. dolazi brodom u Split gdje ga na Rivi čeka masa oduševljenog svijeta.

Naime Andrijica je, po narodnim predanjima, otkupljivao osmansku zemlju za Viničane i gradio im kuće, te darivao konje i krave, što je i bio razlog njegovog općeg simpatiziranja među narodom u Dalmatinskoj Zagori i Hercegovini – unatoč kriminalnoj prošlosti pa ne čudi da mu je u Splitu priređen spektakularan doček.

Svatko je htio toga dana vidjeti živu legendu.

U selima je bio tretiran kao živuća legenda, a Sinjani su ga častili 7 dana te čak proglasili počasnim sudionikom Alke. Upravo tijekom obilježavanja Alke u Sinju i nastaje prikazana fotografija na kojoj Andrijica ponosno pozira fotografu. 1905. umire i biva pokopan u selu Runović u blizini Imotskoga.

Nesumnjivo da je karizma i slava ovog hajduka odigrala i veliku ulogu kod odabira imena splitskog nogometnog kluba Hajduka, a svakako jedan  od najzanimljivijih njegovih opisa pripada Ivanu Mimici (1862. – 1945.) koji je spjevao 3616 deseteraca dok je sa Šimićem služio kaznu u koparskom zatvoru i objavio 1894. godine u Splitu Pjesmu u pet pjevanja o djelovanju Andrije Šimića.

On  piše:

Ja sam imao priliku opetovano viditi Andriju Šimića i s njime razgovarati… Šimić je starčić omalena stasa, malko pognut majci zemlji, visoka čela, bistra oka, izrazita lica, i za čudo, prama svojoj dobi, neobično čvrst, žilav, živan, razgovorljiv i veseo. Od svojih starešina ljubljen je, a od svojih nevoljnih sudrugova čašćen i poštovan. On daje svakomu dobre savjete, svakoga od zla odvraća, i gdje može, pomaže. On znade lijeka proti raznim bolestima, znade protumačiti snove, znade moliti se Bogu i još mnogo dobrih i lijepih stvari on ti znade, samo ne zna psovati i za nikakvo zlo u opće ne zna taj čovjek, odrastao i dorastao medju vucim i hajducim, koji je sam također nosio hajdučki naslov.

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.naslovBlogaEng: Hotel "Jadran" in Jelsa opened its door in May 1911...
blog_graphql.naslovBlogaHr: Hotel Jadran u Jelsi započeo je s radom u svibnju 1911. godine
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
The idea of opening a hotel in Jelsa was suggested to captain Mihovil Zufić (1868-1921) back in 1905 by Jure Duboković (1877-1951), informing that the company NAD would finance both the construction and purchasing the hotel equipment. The hotel had 60 beds and was at that time one of the best equipped hotels in Dalmatia. The rooms had elegant furniture brought from Vienna, while porcelain and silver cutlery were bought in England. The hotel had a reading room and a piano, and the dining room could host 400 people at once. Frano Keko Duboković (1866 – 1929) was in charge of the quality and the furniture, and he put his soul in it. Captain Zufić, who opened and managed the hotel, had s distinguished chevalier’s style which made Jelsa a renowned name. The hotel closed its door in 1913, as the First World War was approaching. After the war it had an array of different managers and from 1934 till 1943 the manager was the son of captain Mihovil, Blaženko Zufić. From 1947 the hotel Jadran was back in business…From an article by Rino Grgićević “Development of tourism in Jelsa”, by kind permission of Mrs. Lukrecija Benković Duboković

What is interesting about this hotel is that a series of its promotional postcards is among the most beautiful tourist postcards of Dalmatia till 1940, as well as a true collector’s delicacy. Today we are familiar with as much as eight samples from the series printed in 1911, showing the hotel lobby, dining room, room interiors, bathing area (3 samples) and hotel exterior (2 samples), but it is not excluded that there is still a sample which has not yet been found. This tells us enough on the entrepreneurship of captain Zufić and his sense of marketing. There are very few small towns in Dalmatia of that time which can brag with such a tourism photography legacy. Some of the postcards from the series were published in the monograph “Greetings from Dalmatia long forgotten”.

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Prijedlog o otvaranju hotela u Jelsi dao je još  1905. g. Jure Duboković (1877. – 1951.) kapetanu  Mihovilu Žufiću (1868. – 1921.) s tim da bi tvrtka NAD financirala izgradnju i nabavu namještaja te opreme za hotel.Hotel je raspolagao sa 60 kreveta i bio, za ono vrijeme, jedan od najbolje opremljenih u Dalmaciji.  Sobe su bile namještene elegantnim namještajem nabavljenim u Beču, a porculan i srebrni  pribor za jelo u Engleskoj. Imao je čitaonicu i klavir, a blagovaonica je mogla ugostiti 400 ljudi odjednom. Za kvalitetu i namještaj zdušno se brinuo Frano Keko Duboković (1866. – 1929.). Kap. Žufić, koji je otvorio i vodio hotel, svojim kavalirskim stilom stvorio je odmah renomirano ime Jelsi. Hotel je 1913., u osvit I. svjetskog rata, neko vrijeme prestao s radom, a  kasnije su se redale razne uprave, da bi ga od 1934. do 1943. vodio sin kap. Mihovila, Blaženko Žufić.  Od 1947. Hotel Jadran nastavlja s radom…

(podatci preuzeti iz članka Rina Grgičevića “Razvoj turizma u Jelsi”, dobrotom gospođe Lukrecije Benković Duboković)

Zanimljivost ovog hotela je i u tome što serija njegovih promidžbenih razglednica spada među najljepše turističke  u Dalmaciji do 1940., te su kolekcionarske poslastice. Danas je poznato čak 8 primjeraka iz serije otisnute 1911. koje prikazuju  predvorje hotela, blagovaonicu, interijere soba, kupalište (3 primjerka ), te eksterijer hotela (2 primjerka), ali nije isključeno da ne postoji još neki primjerak koji do sada nije pronađen. To dovoljno govori o poduzetnosti kapetana Žufića i njegovom smislu za marketing. Vrlo malo manjih gradića u Dalmaciji tog vremena može se pohvaliti takvom turističkom fotografskom ostavštinom. Neke od razglednica iz serije su objavljene u monografiji Pozdrav iz zaboravljene Dalmacije.

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
A small island Krapanj is known as the smallest and the lowest inhabited island in the Adriatic, and it is only 300 meters away from the land. The tradition of sponge harvesting in Krapanj starts back at the end of the 17th century, while the first records on sponge harvesting in the Croatian shore date back to 1522. Two men from Zlarin are mentioned in it, harvesting sponge for a Šibenik dealer who later sold them in Venice.

And how did it all actually begin in Krapanj?

At the end of the 17th century a certain fra Antun came from Crete to serve in the Monastery of Krapanj. In time he started teaching the locals how to harvest and clean the sponge and even organized it to be sold in Venice. In the beginning of harvesting the sponge (“spuga”) was harvested only with spears in lower depths. It was only later that the diving equipment was introduced. By the end of the 19th century the spuga harvesting crew had some eight members and only two or three of them were divers, two were rowers, two were handling the air pump, while two were treading, cleaning and drying the harvested sponges. Back then the sponge harvesting was forbidden every third year so that its habitats would not be devastated.

In 1911 among people who were harvesting sponge on Krapanj there were 16 divers, they had 6 diving devices and 30 boats and they founded a cooperative. Since the Second World War brought some unfortunate losses, the spongers received a financial help from the maritime administration, so in 1930 a small shop opened in Krapanj, processing sponges.

Today in Krapanj there are only several crews for sponge harvesting, and the modernization brought opening of a small refinery for processing, which used to be done manually. People from Krapanj will tell you that spuge harvesting begins with the first summer crickets and ends with coming of October. During winter they are not to be harvested, because that is the beginning of their process of renewal and reproduction. They are very proud of their tradition and it is present everywhere, from the moment you first step on the island where everything is dedicated to sponge.

It takes just a few hours to tour this small island – a visit to the monastery is inevitable – and I would definitely recommend it for its charisma and uniqueness. It is on that island that you will get a glimpse of that authentic, true Dalmatia.

 

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Otočić Krapanj slovi kao najmanji i najniži naseljeni otok na Jadranu, a od kopna ga dijeli samo 300 metara. Tradicija lova na spužve na Krapnju seže od kraja 17. st., dok prvi zapis o lovu spužava na hrvatskoj obali datira iz 1522. godine, a u njemu se spominje vađenje spužava dvojice Zlarinjana za trgovca iz Šibenika koji ih je potom prodavao u Veneciji.

A kako je sve zapravo započelo na Krapnju?

Krajem 17. stoljeća s otoka Krete na otok Krapanj došao je služiti u tamošnji samostan fra Antun koji je  s vremenom mještane naučio brati i čistiti spužve, te je i  organizirao prodaju u Veneciji. U samim začecima lova, spužva (spuga) se vadila samo ostima na manjim dubinama da bi se kasnije polako uvodili i ronilački aparati. Krajem 19. st. posadu za lov na spuge činilo je oko 8 ljudi od kojih su samo dva do tri člana posade bili ronioci, dvojica veslači, dvojica su radila na pumpi za zrak, dok su dvojica gazila, prala i sušila izvađene spužve. Tada je lov spužava bio zabranjen svake treće godine kako se ne bi devastirala njezina staništa.

Godine 1911., spužvari otoka Krapnja sa 16 ronilaca, 6 ronilačkih aparata i 30 brodica osnovali su spužvarsku zadrugu. Zbog nepovoljnih ratnih gubitaka koje je uzrokovao Prvi svjetski rat, od pomorske uprave spužvari su primili financijsku pomoć, te je 1930. godine na Krapnju počela raditi mala radionica za obradu spužava.

Danas na  Krapnju djeluje svega nekoliko posada za lov spužvi, a modernizacija je donijela i otvaranje manje rafinerije za obradu koja se nekad obavljala ručno. Krapljani kažu kako se spuge počinju loviti kad se prvi put na početku ljeta začuju cvrčci, a lovi ih se do listopada. Zimi se ne bi smjele dirati jer im tada traje proces obnove i razmnožavanja. Jako su ponosni na svoju tradiciju i naglašena je svugdje, od prvog stupanja na otok gdje je sve u znaku spužve. Za obilazak ovog otočića, uz nezaobilazan posjet samostanu, potrebno je svega par sati i svakako ga preporučujem zbog njegove karizme i posebnosti, ali i blizine kopna. Vožnja od Brodarice traje desetak minuta, a na njemu ćete osjetiti dašak one prave, istinske Dalmacije.

 

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.naslovBlogaEng: The First World War started back in the 1914 with the assassination of Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo.
blog_graphql.naslovBlogaHr: Daleke 1914. započeo je I. svjetski rat atentatom na Franza (Franju) Ferdinanda u Sarajevu
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
The First World War started back in the 1914 with the assassination of the Austrian Hungarian archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo. This event made the small Dalmatian town Metković the centre of the world because it was the place where the archduke spent his last days of life and also sent off the archduke’s body on its last resting place in Vienna.

The trail of the archduke’s journey to Sarajevo went through Metković, where his arrival was photographed by the Metković’s photographer Nikolac. Nikolac couldn’t even guess that several days later, on the railway station in Metković, he would await the archduke and his wife in their coffins. It was then that several more photographs were made, which showed paying the last honors to the deceased and boarding the coffins of Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sofia Chotek to the yacht Dalmat. Several weeks later, Nikolac printed 10 of his best photographs as postcards (in the form of a convenient block), wanting to mark this event. Today this block is one of the most elite series of Dalmatian postcards, due to its multiple historical and documentary meaning, but also a small circulation, and it is therefore very rare and wanted among postcard collectors, while only two copies are known to be kept in its original form. The postcards from this series were first published in Croatia in the monographs from the series Forgotten Dalmatia.

And the event itself – how did the assassination in Sarajevo happen?

Franz Ferdinand set on his journey off to Sarajevo from Vienna, on June 23rd 1914, on a special train to Trieste. After that he sailed on the military ship SMS Viribus Unitis to the mouth of Neretva, in order to board there the yacht Dalmat (later known as Istranka), which took him all the way to Metković, where there was a solemn reception for him. In Metković there was a special train which set off towards Sarajevo. Franz Ferdinand arrived on June 25th to Sarajevo, where he and his wife Sofia checked into the hotel Bosnia on Ilidža. The Franz Ferdinand’s security was minimal and there were less than 120 police officers in charge of his security. Sofia was thrilled with the reception in Sarajevo. She came to Sarajevo on a train through Budapest and Slavonski Brod, and on every station there was a solemn reception.  While Franz Ferdinand was busy with his political duties, Sofia was visiting the Sarajevo schools, churches and humanitarian institutions.

According to the official plan, from 28th June 1914, Franz Ferdinand was suppose to pay an official visit to Sarajevo before noon, and in the afternoon he was supposed to leave the town and return home through Metković, embarking on a ship. The entire plan of his visit, with exact places which the procession was to pass through, was published a day earlier in the Bosanska pošta. Having learned the procession’s route, the assassinators, members of the terrorist organization “Mlada Bosna” (Young Bosnia) were divided and set on several locations along the route. The goal of this organization was to throw off the Austrian Hungarian authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina through rebellions and armed assassinations.

Having survived the first attempt of an attack with a hand grenade earlier that morning, the archduke went on with his protocol, arriving to the city Hall where he was supposed to listen to the complimentary speech. But before the complimentary speech, he excitedly criticized the Sarajevo mayor, Fehrim Čurčić, saying: “Mister mayor, I have come here to visit you, and they are throwing bombs at me. This is outrageous.” It was only after countess Sofia whispered something in his ear, that Franz Ferdinand calmed down somewhat and allowed mayor Čurčić to continue with his speech. After the speech the officials and members of the Franz Ferdinand’s entourage discussed what should they do. Finally, Franz Ferdinand and Sofia gave up on the official plan and decided to visit the victims of the bomb attack.

When heading to the hospital the driver started off the wrong way, so he had to stop and go back. It is that exact moment that the assassinator Gavrilo Princip used to shoot, hitting thus both Franz and Sofia, who both passed away shortly after. How shocking and unbelievable for everyone present! The assassinators were caught right away and soon condemned.

The bodies of Franz Ferdinand and Sofia were in the end transferred to Metković on 30th June 1914, embarked on the yacht Dalmat which took them to SMS Viribus Unitis, in Trieste, and later back to Vienna. Everything that followed was well known and recorded in the world history. No one could have even imagined that this event would mark the beginning of the First World War and a million of dead people.

 

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Daleke 1914. započeo je I. svjetski rat atentatom na austrougarskog nadvojvodu Franza (Franju) Ferdinanda u Sarajevu. Ovaj događaj  učinio je na trenutak maleni dalmatinski gradić Metković centrom svijeta jer je svjedočio posljednjim danima života prijestolonasljednika, ali ga i nedugo potom mrtvog ispratio na posljednje počivalište u Beč.

Trasa njegovog putovanja za Sarajevo vodila  je upravo preko Metkovića gdje je njegov  dolazak fotografirao metkovski fotograf Jure Nikolac koji nije mogao ni slutiti da će par dana nakon tog dana  dočekati  nadvojvodu i njegovu suprugu na željezničkoj stanici u Metkoviću u mrtvačkim kovčezima. Tada nastaje još nekoliko fotografija koje prikazuju posljednju počast te ukrcaj ljesova Franza Ferdinanda i njegove supruge Sofije Chotek na brod Dalmat. Nikolac je nekoliko tjedana kasnije, 10 najboljih fotografija tiskao kao razglednice (u formi prigodnog  bloka) čime je htio obilježiti  ovaj događaj.  Danas je taj blok jedna od najelitnijih serija dalmatinskih razglednica zbog višestrukog povijesnog i dokumentarnog značaja i male tiraže, te je vrlo  rijedak i tražen među kolekcionarima razglednica, a zna se za samo dva sačuvana kompleta u izvornom obliku. Razglednice iz ove serije  prvi put u Hrvatskoj objavljene su u monografijama iz serijala Zaboravljena Dalmacija.

A sam događaj?  Kako je došlo do atentata u Sarajevu?

Franjo Ferdinand krenuo je iz Beča za Sarajevo 23. lipnja 1914. godine, posebnim vlakom do Trsta. Potom je vojnim brodom SMS Viribus Unitis doplovio do ušća Neretve, da bi se onda ukrcao na jahtu Dalmat (kasnije znana kao Istranka) kojom je doplovio do Metkovića gdje mu je bio pripremljen svečani doček. U Metkoviću ga je dočekao posebni vlak kojim je krenu za Sarajevo u koje je doputovao 25. lipnja te je sa suprugom Sofijom odsjeo u hotelu Bosna na Ilidži. Osiguranje Franje Ferdinda u Sarajevu bilo je minimalno, oko 120 policijskih službenika zaduženih za njegovu sigurnost.  Sofija je bila oduševljena dočekom u Sarajevu. Ona je putovala vlakom preko Budimpešte i Slavonskog Broda, te joj je na svim stanicama bio priređen svečani doček. Dok je nadvojvoda bio zauzet državničkim dužnostima, Sofija je posjećivala sarajevske škole, crkve i dobrotvorne ustanove.

Po službenom planu, od 28. lipnja 1914., Franjo Ferdinand je trebao službeno posjetiti Sarajevo prijepodne, a poslijepodne je već trebao napustiti grad i vratit se preko Metkovića brodom kući. Cjelokupan program njegovog posjeta, s točnim mjestima koja će povorka obići,  dan ranije je objavio list Bosanska pošta. Saznavši rutu povorke, atentatori, pripadnici terorističke organizacije Mlada Bosna raspodijelili su se na nekoliko lokacija. Cilj ove tajne organizacije bio je pobunama i  atentatima zbaciti austrougarsku vlast u Bosni i Hercegovini.

Iako je prvi pokušaj napada ručnom bombom to jutro nadvojvoda preživio, ipak je nastavio s protokolom došavši do gradske vijećnice gdje je trebao poslušati pozdravni govor. No, uzbuđeno je kritizirao gradonačelnika Sarajeva  Fehrima Čurčića izjavivši: Gospodine gradonačelniče, došao sam ovdje u posjet, a na mene bacaju bombe. To je nečuveno. Tek nakon što mu je grofica Sofija prišapnula nešto u uho, Franjo Ferdinand se donekle smirio i dopustio gradonačelniku Čurčiću nastaviti s govorom. Službenici i pripadnici pratnje prijestolonasljednika nakon govora su raspravljali što dalje učiniti. Franjo Ferdinand i Sofija naposljetku su odustali od službenog plana i odlučili da će u bolnici posjetiti žrtve bombaškog napada.

Na putu prema bolnici vozač je pogriješio te morao zastati i krenuti unatrag. Upravo taj trenutak iskoristio je atentator Gavrilo Princip zapucavši te pritom pogodivši i Franza i Sofiju koji su nedugo nakon toga preminuli. Kakav šok i nevjerica za sve prisutne. Atentatori su odmah uhvaćeni i ubrzo osuđeni.

Tijela Franje Ferdinanda i Sofije 30. lipnja 1914. su vlakom prenesena do Metkovića, ukrcana na jahtu Dalmat koja ih je Neretvom prevezla do ušća gdje su prenesena na SMS Viribus Unitis, do Trsta, a potom i natrag do Beča. Sve što je uslijedilo, dobro je poznato u svjetskoj povijesti, nitko nije mogao  ni slutiti da će ovaj događaj dovesti do početka I. svjetskog rata i milijuna mrtvih.

 

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
During my peregrinations through Dalmatia and my visitations to the oldest and most charismatic houses, I finally came to the famed house Mimbelli in Orebić. I heard people talk about this beauty on many occasions and I was planning to photograph it for a long time and present it to a wider public. Finally I managed to do it. My host was its present owner Ivica who was thrilled to tell me everything about the house’s rich history. The adrenalin which takes over every visitor of this beauty when they enter is just indescribable. It is instant and it teleports you right into its rich past.

The house was built in 18th century by the members of Mimbelli family, famous shipowners who gained their wealth from wheat trade through Russia and China. In the brightest moments of their business they decided to present their wealth through such a palace in a small town like Orebić. The most expensive pieces of furniture were ordered, the family paid attention to every detail. Most of the original pieces of furniture are still preserved and smiling to the visitors. The Wiehler gobelins, Biedermeier furniture, antique Murano chandeliers, dressers made of rosewood from Kashmir, Belgian and English porcelain, copper dishes and an entire row of details made this house one of the most exclusive ones in Dalmatia of that time. Such luxury when choosing the most expensive materials of that time should not come as a surprise because Mimbelli’s were extremely rich, and at the peak of their power they had as many as 33 sailing boats, which they used to sell the Russian wheat all over the world. When decorating the house in Orebić, the family went so far as to order that the walls be manually painted. So in the end as much as 4 million egg yolks were used for this undertaking. What says the most of that quality is also the fact that the walls are still mostly preserved – excellent and authentic, almost 300 hundred years after they were painted. In time, the house was enriched with souvenirs coming from the Far East. Among other objects there was a Ming dynasty vase which was stolen during the partisans’ rampage and pillage during the Second World War.

There is an interesting story about the ending of the Mimbelli lineage in Orebić. Anton Mimbelli brought a governess from Russia, and his only son Baldo fell in love with her daughter. Since the parents thought she was lowly and of other religion, the marriage could not receive their blessing, and in spite of them Baldo swore he would never get married. And so it was, and in his will Baldo asked to be buried in Orebić, where he ordered a family mausoleum to be constructed by the great Croatian sculptor Ivan Rendić. In his testament he asked for the mausoleum’s dome to be painted in gold every two years, so that the passers-by would see that there lay the Mimbelli family, on the cemetery above Orebić. And the beautiful girl, symbolizing Baldo’s unfortunate love, was carved inside the mausoleum, and covered in golden leaves. This is an incredibly sumptuous tomb of the family which left an indelible trace in the history of Orebić, especially as donors and benefactors who provided finances to construct the city water system, renew the Franciscan church, etc…

Before his death Baldo sold the house to a famous maritime family Župa, whose last descendant, Matko, passed away in 2004. Matko was a famous collector, one of the founders of the Maritime museum in Orebić and its long-term director, as well as the director of the Korčula tourist board. As a memorable person on Pelješac he used to host different ambassadors in the Mimbelli house, as well as actors, writers and other highly positioned personalities from the former state. Everyone, absolutely everyone who travelled through Pelješac and Korčula wanted to spend at least one night there. There was even a well known saying that only the president Tito never dropped by. Had he known what kind of labels the vine basement hid, he would have probably not missed the opportunity.

 

A charismatic beauty as this one surely does not exist today in Dalmatia and had the circumstances been different, the state apparatus would have repurchased it a long time ago from its previous owners.

Igor Goleš

Tijekom svojih đirada po Dalmaciji i obilaženja najstarijih i najkarizmatičnijih kuća, došao sam i do čuvene kuće Mimbelli u Orebiću. Slušao sam o ovoj ljepotici u više navrata te dugo planirao snimiti je i pokazati široj publici. Naposljetku sam i uspio.  Ugostio me  njen današnji vlasnik Ivica i oduševljeno prepričao njenu bogatu povijest. Adrenalin koji  svakog posjetioca ove ljepotice prožme prilikom ulaska jednostavno je jednostavno, djeluje trenutno te vas teleportira u njenu bogatu prošlost.

Kuću su sagradili u 18. st. pripadnici obitelji Mimbelli, čuveni brodovlasnici koji su se obogatili trgovanjem žitom preko Rusije i Kine te su, u najsvjetlijim trenucima svog poslovanja, odlučili svoju moć i  bogatstvo prezentirati gradnjom jedne ovakve palače upravo u malom Orebiću. Naručivali su se najskuplji komadi namještaja, pazilo se na svaki detalj, a mnogi  od prvotnih komada namještaja se i danas neuništivo smješkaju posjetiteljima – Wiehlerovi gobleni, bidermajeri, antikni murano lusteri, komoda od drva ruže iz Kašmira,  belgijski i engleski porculan, bakreno posuđe te niz drugih detalja,  učinili su ovu kuću jednom od najekskluzivnijih u Dalmaciji tog vremena. Ovakva raskoš kod odabira najskupljih materijala tog vremena ne treba čuditi jer Mimbelliji su bili ekstremno bogati, a na vrhuncu svoje moći imali su čak 33 jedrenjaka kojima su trgovali ruskim žitom po cijelom svijetu. U svom ukrašavaju kuće u Orebiću obitelj je išla toliko daleko da su naručili i oslikavanje svih zidova pa je naposljetku utrošeno čak 4 milijuna žumanjaka u ovaj pothvat. O kvaliteti rada i danas nam svjedoče zidovi koji su, u najvećoj mjeri, izvrsno i autentično očuvani, gotovo 300 godina nakon oslikavanja. S vremenom, kuća se oplemenjivala suvenirima s dalekog istoka pa je, između ostalog, u njoj bila i vaza iz dinastije Ming koja je otuđena u partizanskom divljanju i pljačkaju tijekom II. svjetskog rata.

Uz kraj loze Mimbelli u Orebiću veže se zanimljiva priča. Anton Mimbelli doveo je iz Rusije  guvernantu u čiju se kćer njegov sin jedinac Baldo zaljubio. S obzirom na to da su roditelji smatrali da je ona nižeg roda i druge vjere nisu mogli blagosloviti taj brak, a Baldo se u inat njima zakleo da se nikada neće ženiti. Tako je i bilo. Baldo je oporučno zaželio da bude pokopan u Orebiću gdje je i naručio izradu obiteljskog mauzoleja  od velikog hrvatskog kipara Ivana Rendića. U testamentu je zaželio da se kupola mauzoleja svako dvije godine boji zlatnom bojom kako bi svi prolaznici vidjeli da na groblju povrh Orebića počiva obitelj Mimbelli, a sama isklesana ljepotica u mauzoleju koja simbolizira Baldovu nesretnu ljubav ukrašena je zlatnim listićima. Nevjerojatno raskošna grobnica obitelji koja je ostavila veliki trag u povijesti Orebića, osobito kao donatori i dobrotvori koji su financirali izgradnju gradskog vodovoda, obnovu franjevačke crkve itd.

Baldo je prije svoje smrti kuću proda slavnoj orebićkoj pomorskoj obitelji Župa čiji posljednji potomak Matko umire 2004. Matko je bio poznat kao veliki kolekcionar, jedan od osnivača Pomorskog muzeja u Orebiću i njegov dugogodišnji ravnatelj te direktor turističke zajednice općine Korčula. Kao znamenita osoba na Pelješcu često je u kući  Mimbelli ugošćivao razne veleposlanike, glumce i književnike, te druge visoko pozicionirane osobe iz bivše države. Svi, apsolutni svi,  koji su bili na proputovanju Pelješcem i Korčulom htjeli su tu provesti barem jednu noć. Poznata je izreka da jedino predsjednik Tito nije u tu kuću svratio, a da je znao kakve etikete je krio njen vinski podrum vjerojatno to ne bi ni on propustio.

Još jedna ovako karizmatična ljepotica zasigurno ne postoji danas u Dalmaciji i u nekim drugim okolnostima, država bi je odavno otkupila od sadašnjih vlasnika.

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
Baron Gautsch was a passenger steamship of the Austrian company Lloyd. It was built in 1908 in the shipyard Gourlay Brothers Company Ltd. in Dundee, Great Britain. It was 84,55 meters long and beside 64 crew members, it could transport up to 300 passengers. It plied its regular line Trieste-Kotor-Trieste.

This beautiful ship was truly representative and luxurious and its beauty would leave everyone breathless. As such it often appeared as a motive on old postcards. In Dalmatia it would dock in Zadar, Split and Dubrovnik.

When the First World War started, on 27th July 1914, the ship was rented by the Austrian-Hungarian war navy to transfer reinforcements to Kotor. During the four trips under the rental contract the ship sailed 1810 nautical miles and transferred 2885 persons. On returning to northern Adriatic, the ship evacuated the civilians.

After all the reinforcements were transferred, the Baron Gautsch was returned to Lloyd in Kotor. Before the ship set sail towards Kotor, a conference of war navy authorities was held in Trieste, and second officer Tenze took part in it, representing his captain Paul Winter. At the conference the ship commanders were informed on the fact that the Austrian Hungarian forces would lay minefields in the northern Adriatic in order to protect the entrance to Pula, its main war port. Tenze informed his captain on that, and the first officer Luppis set the ship course.

It set sail on its last journey on 12th August 1914 from Kotor. The next day, on August 13th 1914 at 11 AM, it set sail from Veli Lošinj directly to its main port Trieste, where it should have arrived at 6 PM. From Lošinj to Pula the ship was under commandment of the first officer Luppis. However, he deserted the ship without the captain’s permission in order to have lunch with the first class passengers, handing over the command to the second officer Tenze.

Barun Gautsch set sail much more up north than the military authorities ordered. The ship crossed paths with another ship, Prinz Hohenlohe, which was sailing south towards the Dalmatian islands, over three nautical miles further from the coastline than Baron Gautsch. Tenze refused to change the sailing course, not even after several passengers warned him.

Seven nautical miles from the Brijuni islands, at 2.50 PM, the steamship sailed full speed into the friendly minefield, which had just been laid by the Dual Monarchy minelayers. The minelayer Basilisk sent its warning signals, but Barun Gautsch did not respond. Having come across a mine, the ship sank six nautical miles southeast from the lighthouse Sv. Ivan na pučini. According to the official data, the ship carried 246 passengers (this number did not include children up to 10 years nor conscripts). Most of the children drowned. The sailors managed to lower the life saving boats into the sea and board the children, but amongst all the panic no one remembered to untie the ropes, so when sinking, the steamship pulled down the boats with children. It seems those poor kids were the first victims of the First World War.

This huge tragedy is remembered as the greatest sea tragedy in the Adriatic, with a great number of victims, so the Baron Gautsch is often called the Titanic of the Adriatic sea. Today its wreck is still a favorite diving destination.

 

Igor Goleš

Baron Gautsch bio je putnički parobrod Austrijskoga Lloyda. Izgrađen je 1908. u brodogradilištu Gourlay Brothers Company Ltd. u Dundeeju u Velikoj Britaniji. Bio je dug 84,55 m, a uz 64 člana posade, mogao je prevesti i 300 putnika. Prometovao je na redovitoj liniji Trst – Kotor – Trst.

Ovaj prekrasan brod bio je za to doba itekako reprezentativan i luksuzan. Ostavljao je svojom ljepotom bez daha te se zbog toga često pojavljivao kao motiv na starim razglednicama. U Dalmaciji je pristajao u Zadru, Splitu i Dubrovniku.

Kada je izbio Prvi svjetski rat, brod je 27. srpnja 1914. unajmila austrougarska ratna mornarica radi prijevoza pojačanja do Kotora. Tijekom četiri putovanja pod ugovorom o najmu preplovio je  1810 nautičkih milja i prevezao 2855 osoba. Na povratku u sjeverni Jadran njime su evakuirani civili.

Nakon što su sva pojačanja prevezena, Baron Gautsch vraćen je Lloydu u Kotor. Prije nego je isplovio za Kotor u Trstu je održana konferencija između ratnih mornaričkih vlasti na kojoj je sudjelovao drugi časnik Tenze koji je zastupao svog kapetana Paula Wintera. Na konferenciji su zapovjednici brodova bili informirani o tome da će austro-ugarske snage položiti minska polja u sjevernom Jadranu radi zaštite ulaza u Pulu, svoju glavnu ratnu luku. Tenze je o tome izvijestio svog kapetana, a prvi časnik Luppis odredio je kurs broda.

Na svoje posljednje putovanje isplovio je 12. kolovoza 1914. iz Kotora. Sljedećeg dana, 13. kolovoza 1914., u 11 sati isplovio je s Velog Lošinja izravno za matičnu luku Trst gdje je trebao stići u 18 sati. Od Lošinja do Pule brod je bio pod zapovjedništvom prvog časnika Luppisa. No, on je napustio most bez kapetanova dopuštenja zbog ručka s putnicima iz prvog razreda te je službu predao drugom časniku Tenzeu.

Baron Gautsch započeo je plovidbu sjeverno, mnogo bliže nego su vojne vlasti zapovjedile.  Mimoišao se s brodom Prinz Hohenlohe koji je plovio južno prema dalmatinskim otocima više od 3 nautičke milje dalje od obale nego Baron Gautsch. Čak ni upozorenja nekoliko putnika nisu uspjela natjerati Tenzea da promijeni smjer plovidbe.

Sedam nautičkih milja od Brijunskih otoka u 14:50 parobrod je punom brzinom naišao na prijateljsko minsko polje koje su upravo položili K.u.K. minopolagači. Minopolagač Basilisk odaslao je signale upozorenja, no Barun Gautsch nije na njih reagirao. Nakon nailaska na minu, brod je potonuo šest nautičkih milja jugozapadno od svjetionika Sv. Ivan na pučini. Prema službenim podatcima, na brodu je bilo 246 putnika (podatak ne obuhvaća djecu do 10 godina i vojnike). Djeca su se, uglavnom, sva utopila. Mornari su uspjeli spustiti čamce za spašavanje i ukrcati u njih djecu, no nitko se u panici nije sjetio odriješiti užeta pa ih je tonući parobrod povukao za sobom. Ta su jadna djeca bila, čini se, prve žrtve Prvoga svjetskoga rata.

Ova ogromna tragedija zapamćena je kao najveća pomorska nesreća na Jadranu, s velikim brojem žrtava, stoga često Barona Gautscha nazivaju jadranskim Titanicom. Danas je njegova olupina omiljena ronilačka destinacija.

Igor Goleš

Is there a greater pilgrimage to Our Lady in Dalmatia than the one to the Miraculous Lady of Sinj?

Every August 15th hoards of people come to Sinj in order to vow the health of their dearest ones. Croatians and Dalmatians have actually always worshipped the Blessed Virgin Mary, turning to her for help during the hard and troubled times. They believed in her celestial intercession, honoring her for gratitude as the Queen of Croats. They have also invoked her through history as fidelissima advocata Croatiae (the most devoted advocate of Croats).

How did the cult of Lady of Sinj actually commence?

The image of the Lady of Sinj was brought from Rama in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1687, fleeing to Dalmatia in fear of Turkish revenge. Those were the hard times when the Turks were at war with the Venetians, constantly persecuting Christians along the borders. The whirl of war came to Sinj in 1715, when the Bosnian pasha, Mehmed Pasha Celic came down Prolog on 23th July with 60.000 of soldiers. The Turks later conquered Sinj. The attack on Sinj became on August 8th. For four days the Turks were ruthlessly firing cannons on Sinj, and on 14th August the Mehmed Pasha ordered general onslaught. People started panicking because there were 60.000 of Turks and not even a thousand of defenders and common people. In the height of Turkish attacks, the friars took out the image of Our Lady and started praying to her. Common people joined the friars and for two days and nights they have prayed, asking the Lady to help them. The strongest attack took place in the night from 14th to 15th, when a miracle happened. Surrounded by a strong light, wearing white, the Lady appeared on the city walls, looked at the believers and stretched her arms towards the Turks. Fear arose among them, and they started to retreat. At daybreak of the Assumption of Mary feast Mehmed Pasha Celic ended the siege and ran away.

The people ascribed this miraculous victory to the grace of their Lady, so as a sign of gratitude the believers and the friars who survived, made a golden frame for the image and called it the Miraculous Lady of Sinj. In the Church of Miraculous Lady of Sinj the image can still be seen with the inscription: IN PERPETUUM CORONATA TRIUMPHAT – ANNO MDCCXV (May you triumph forever crowned – year 1715) which is carried every year in procession through the town on 15th August.

In honor of this great victory Sinjska alka is held every year in Sinj, on the first Sunday in August.

Igor Goleš

U čast ove velike pobjede održava se u Sinju svake godine i Sinjska alka, prve nedjelje u mjesecu kolovozu.

 

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Svakog 15. kolovoza rijeke ljudi se slijevaju u Sinj kako bi se Gospi zavjetovale na zdravlje svojih najmilijih. Hrvati i dalmatinci su zapravo oduvijek štovali Blaženu Djevicu Mariju i u teškim vremenima i nevoljama molili joj se za pomoć. Pouzdali se se u njezin nebeski zagovor časteći je iz zahvalnosti kao kraljicu Hrvata. Zazivali su je kroz povijest i fidelissima advocata Croatiae (najvjernija odvjetnica Hrvata).

Kako je zapravo započeo kult štovanja Gospe Sinjske?

Sliku Gospe su u Sinj donijeli fratri iz Rame u Bosni i Hercegovini, bježeći u strahu od turske odmazde. Bila su to teška vremena kada su turci ratovali s Mlečanima i neprestalno proganjali kršćane po pograničnim područjima. Ratni vihor došao je i do Sinja 1715. kada se bosanski paša, Mehmed-paša Čelić sa šezdeset tisuća vojnika 23. srpnja 1715. god. spustio niz Prolog. Turci su potom opkolili Sinj. Napad na Sinj otpočeo je 8. kolovoza. Toga dana izgorjela je Gospina crkva pod Kamičkom i crkva svetoga Franje. Četiri su dana Turci nemilice iz topova tukli Sinj, a 14. kolovoza Mehmed-paša zapovjedio je opći juriš.  U to su vrijeme starci, žene, djeca i nemoćni svećenici kroz plač i suze molili pred Gospinom slikom koju su stavili na oltar svete Barbare u crkvi svetoga Mihovila u središtu Sinjske tvrđave. Ljude je uhvatila panika jer je Turaka bilo šezdeset tisuća a branitelja i puka ukupno niti tisuću. U jeku turskih napada  fratri su izvadili sliku Gospe i počeli joj se moliti. Fratrima se pridružio i obični narod i dva dana i dvi noći neprekidno su molili Gospu da im pomogne. Najveća navala je bila sa 14. na 15. na Gospin žežen, a 15.tog se desilo čudo. Sva u bijelom pojavila se Gospa na gradskim zidinama, pogledala u svoje vjernike i ispružila ruku prema Turcima. Među njima je zavladala žeđ, dizenterija i strah, a u osvit Velike Gospe Mehmed-paša  Čelić prekinuo je opsadu i pobjegao.

Narod je prepisao ovu čudesnu pobjedu milosti njihove Gospe, stoga su u znak zahvalnosti vjernici i fratri koji su preživjeli čudotvornoj slici napravili zlatni okvir i prozvali je Čudotvorna Gospa Sinjska. U crkvi Čudotvorne Gospe Sinjske i danas se može vidjeti slika sa natpisom: IN ERPETUUM CORONATA TRIUMPHAT – ANNO MDCCXV (Zauvijek okrunjena slavi slavlje – godine 1715.) koja se svake godine iznosi u procesiji gradom na 15. kolovoza.

U čast ove velike pobjede održava se u Sinju svake godine i Sinjska alka, prve nedjelje u mjesecu kolovozu.

 

Igor Goleš

blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
It is not in vain that people say that the moment you put your finger in the sea you are universally connected with the entire world.
This is a true thesis on the sea and people worth for everyone, especially for those who live and feel the sea, deeply rooted inside them. It is so with our sea, too, the blessed indented shoreline which wrinkles its lovely face, making it thus an even prettier old man. So much could be said and written about it, but in this book that tells a story on postcards we can only in the end present those most special ones that connect Dalmatia with the rest of the Croatian Adriatic.

A mini chapter in front of you represents its particularities. Numerous inhabitants of its depths with rich fauna, as well as its luminous guides – lighthouses. While the series of postcards with the Adriatic fish, made in 1898 by the Lošinj photographer Benedikt Lergetporer, is absolutely unique and surely among the oldest photographs with this topic, the postcards with the lighthouse motifs done in commercial circulations, on the other hand, are also less surprising. From today’s perspective it is truly amazing that Lergetporer came up with the idea to arrange with the local fishermen to record for eternity their everyday catches and use these photographs as templates for making photo-postcards. Their circulation is very questionable as well as the question if there is any similar postcard from that opus. The eight postcards shown with the motifs of the Adriatic fish were found in Vienna, where they have spent over a hundred years in an album, an integral part of the Lergetporer’s opus which was made up of as much as 96 postcards of the island of Lošinj, taken in the period from 1897 till 1905. The entire album was bought in 2014, at the auction in Salzburg, by the collector Franko Neretich who keeps collecting patiently and with nostalgia in the far-away New York everything that is dear to his heart, regarding his native island and the Adriatic. Revealing these postcards can be called sensational, because from that time, and also later there just aren’t any postcards with similar motifs. They are far more than a mere piece of paper, a memory of all the fishermen and their sleepless nights, horny hands, worn out from pulling out the nets, rowing and everyday fight to survive. It is also a memory of the wealth of one of the clearest seas in the world.

Unfortunately, we don’t have the opportunity to see the postcard showing the sardine – the feeder of the poor, even though the Lošinj archipelago was teeming with this blue fish at that time. Throughout the Adriatic at the beginning of the 20th century there were factories for processing sardines, which employed thousands of workers. Only in Komiža, on the island of Vis, there were six of them. Today all of these factories are empty, in the places which slowly die out, and they are decaying under salt and rust. The salt of that same sea which used to give away, and today it is roaring: Oh, yes, you humble servants, you will remember the days when you were blessed with abundance, and already now you are crying for the damage and neglect which you caused by your disrespect for me!
Just as all that bustle in the sardine factories and the worker passion are long gone, so did that same sardine disappear at the beginning of the new millennium for several years from the depths of the Adriatic sea, and that fairly frightened all those who live of the sea and with the sea. As expected, the question arose whether that was the beginning of the end… or not yet, but only a reminder of how many spices are threatened and might die out. With nostalgia, I remembered the stories of the Lastovo fishermen how, back in time, at the period of lobsters spawning, one could have watched from the coast tenths of their tentacles peeping from the shallows of the crystal clear sea, which is today considered to be just wild imagination. The habitats of this unique crab are almost destroyed today, because of the modern ways of fishing and often uncontrolled overfishing. But it is not only lobster that is endangered, but also other heroes from these postcards: John Dory, shrimps, red mullet… Is it possible that Lergetporer, like Nostradamus, foresaw that someday instead of going to the fish market and enjoying the Mediterranean folklore which it offers, we would carry these fish only in our memories, so he decided to give them main roles in his deltiology play. I believe not, the motive was strictly creative, and let us hope that the human consciousness will be triggered in time and give us strength to face the challenges of the modern ages and preserve the seas and their fauna.
Therefore, let the main protagonists of these eight postcards shown not remain just mere memories, but our everyday life like the lighthouses are, which represent a special addition to time when one was sailing on the Adriatic without the contemporary navigation devices, and the ships were prowled by many rocks, invisible to the naked eye.
The light that is reflected from these stone titans saved lives, opened paths towards Italy in the north and the Mediterranean in the south, made the Adriatic safe for navigation. The construction started as early as in the 19th century, when the lighthouses were built along the natural shipping lines. The first one was built and finished on the cape Savudrija in 1818. There is a story connected to its construction, deserving of greatest love dramas. Namely, a respected Austrian politician met a young Croatian girl during a ball on a Vienna court. The amount of the emotions and the affection that took him over took him quickly back to his youth and, having won her over, the unfortunate lover began thinking on how they could spend time together without compromising his social status and marriage. She persuaded him to come to Istria and, upon seeing the cape Savudrija, right away he thought that if he were to build a lighthouse far away from the sights of curious eyes he might come and spend time with his lover undisturbed. Unfortunately, the young lady did not live to see the end of the construction of the lighthouse, because she fell ill and died, and the Savudrija lighthouse was and overture to building dozens of others throughout the Adriatic in the course of the century.
It is hard to say whether the other lighthouses have also been made under the same disguises or building some of their own legends, but one thing that is sure is that due to their dislocation some mystical stories are always tied to lighthouses, making people call them unknown, mysterious, surreal… It is, therefore, not strange that the lighthouse keepers, in those few not automated lighthouses with human crew, are characterized as loners and weirdoes, although we can only be jealous of the life they live, far away from the modern urban ant hills, where our busy rhythm of life does not let us go back to our true roots. They know with how much joy they go back to their lighthouses after just a short staying in the grotto of civilization. And we, how wrong we are in our beliefs, because, really, is there anything prettier than waking up to the sound of the waves and scent of the sea, disturbed only by shrieks of seagulls, and falling asleep on the blue rays of happiness and serenity.

The dislocation contributed also to the lighthouses being rarely visited by the photographers wanting to record them and print just like classical postcards. That is why they seem so exotic in the old postcards. Those in the northern Adriatic are less rare, even though that is not a rule, while in the entire Dalmatia there are just several postcards of the lighthouses, and these are with the motifs of Veli Rat, Palagruža, Mulo near Rogoznica and Pokonji dol near Hvar, although there are far more of them built.
The situation is somewhat improved by the photo-postcards which reveal to us the lighthouse Stončica, as well as some war events like the multiple cannon shooting of the Austrian navy on the beautiful Palagruža in 1915. Thanks to a military photographer from the Austrian torpedo boats, a series of several postcards is a witness of this event today, including the bombing of the island, as well as the final act – the devastation of this monumental edifice. The war propaganda was very active in glorifying successes, so soldiers would often send postcards like this to their families, in order to depict their military war adventures. The Palagruža lighthouse was restored after the World War One finished. A definitely interesting piece of data is the one saying that the demolished lighthouse was known for the strongest light, which could be seen even 26 nautical miles away.
The oldest lighthouse built in Dalmatia back in 1849 is one called Veli Rat on Dugi otok and it has the highest tower among all the lighthouses in the Adriatic. It is known for the fact that as much as 100.000 egg yolks were spent to make its yellow frontage.
Mulo near Rogoznica was first photographed by Ante Vlahović, a dilettante photographer, who used to work as a teacher in Mandalina, and he often came to Rogoznica on weekends, coming to see his uncle, a parson. It was exactly that one, together with some other Vlahović’s photographs, that were published as the first series of Rogoznica postcards in 1899, so Mulo obtained the title of the first Dalmatian lighthouse on a postcard. Today there are only four samples, which are carefully kept in private collections in Rogoznica, Split, Zagreb and Venice. It is the femme fatale, the undreamt dream of numerous collectors.
The photographers mostly took photos of lighthouses so that the monumental towers can be seen, as well as the buildings, so an entirely atypical postcard of the lighthouse in the island of Susak from 1899 is pure joy. It shows the entrance to the building with the inscription PHARUS SANSEGO …, and the family of the lighthouse keeper, excited about the guests arriving, cannot hide smiles on their faces. The entire happening is greeted also by the song of the European goldfinch, coming from the cage hung right by the door, seeming like the birds would like to have a concert in front of the auditorium which was never bigger. This is also a very rare example, witness of the life on the lighthouses in the 19th century.
Each of these few postcards hides a story about itself. They are, definitely, a very important side of the nautical culture of the Croatian Adriatic and they make us think. Today an unnecessary and pointless question is asked – did all those lighthouses, which the Austrian-Hungarian Monarchy built along the Adriatic coast during the 19th century, disturb in fact the natural harmony and peace on all these islets and capes. Now, when the conscience of the ecology is raised, we seem to forget how many ship wrecks have been avoided, and how many lives were saved thanks to these rocky keepers, scattered among 1244 of islands, isles, islets and ridges of the Croatian Adriatic. In front of us there is a new imperative, to nourish and cherish each and every one of them, as the most fragile lace in the chest hiding the dowry of a bride to be, so that their lustre would never fade away. The global glory which was transferred by thousands of tourists who visit them each year will definitely contribute to this. How many special features are hidden in these pearls if someone is ready to fly across the world in order to spend here the most important days of the year, days when one should in a meditative surroundings renew each atom of their energy and regenerate oneself in order to lose the stress. Are WE really aware of the beauty which we are surrounded by?
We are left with nothing but keeping what we inherited, and the being aware of the existence of postcards like this definitely helps here. We, the collectors, will keep searching for them, deeply immersed in the whirls of the most exotic talks, thinking how some day the postcards with motifs of sardines and lobsters would appear in front of us, along with the postcards with the lighthouses on Sušac or Blitvenica, Grujica or Prišnjak. Will our collectors’ dreams come true, and will the fish and the lanterns of the Adriatic survive – time will tell. Let us wish them and us all the luck!

Ne kažu uzalud da onog trena kada staviš prst u more ostvariš univerzalnu povezanost sa cijelim svijetom.
Istinita je to teza o moru i ljudima koja vrijedi za svih, posebice za one koji more žive i osjećaju ukorijenjeno duboko u sebi. Tako je i s našim morem, blagoslovljenim razvedenom obalom koja mu nabora milo lice, čineći ga time još ljepšim starcem. O njemu bi se moglo mnogo toga izreći i napisati, ali u ovoj knjizi koja priča o razglednicama možemo tek na kraju predstaviti one najposebnije koje povezuju Dalmaciju s ostatkom hrvatskog Jadrana.


Mini poglavlje koje je pred vama predstavlja njegove posebnosti. Brojne stanovnike njegovih faunom bogatih dubina, kao i njegove svjetlonosne vodiče – svjetionike. Dok je serija razglednica jadranskih riba, koju je 1904. napravio lošinjski fotograf Benedikt Lergetporer, apsolutno unikatna i zasigurno spada među najstarije fotografije ovakve tematike, dotle su razglednice s motivima svjetionika izrađivane u komercijalnim nakladama i manje iznenađujuće. Iz današnje perspektive naprosto je nevjerojatna činjenica da je Lergetporer došao na ideju da u suradnji s lokalnim ribarima ovjekovječi njihove svakodnevne ulove i te fotografije upotrijebi kao predloške za izradu foto-razglednica. Vrlo je upitna njihova tiraža i postoji li još neka slična razglednica iz tog opusa. Prikazanih osam razglednica s motivima jadranskih riba pronađene su u Beču gdje su više od 100 godina u albumu bile sastavni dio Lergetporerova opusa od čak 96 razglednica otoka Lošinja, iz razdoblja od 1897. do 1905. Čitav album kupio je 2014., na aukciji u Salzburgu, kolekcionar Franko Neretich koji iz dalekog New Yorka sakuplja strpljivo i nostalgično sve srcu milo, vezano uz rodni otok i Jadran. Otkriće ovih razglednica može se nazvati senzacionalnim jer iz tog vremena, ali i kasnije jednostavno ne postoje neke sličnih motiva. One su više od pukog komada papira, spomenar na sve ribare i njihove neprospavane noći, žuljevite ruke, izmorene od izvlačenja mreža, veslanja i svakodnevne borbe za preživljavanje. Spomenar je to i na bogatstvo jednog od najčistijih mora na svijetu.
Nažalost, ovdje nemamo prigodu vidjeti razglednicu koja prikazuje srdelu – hraniteljicu siromašnih, iako je lošinjski arhipelag u to vrijeme obilovao ovom plavom ribom. Diljem Jadrana početkom 20. stoljeća postojale su mnogobrojne tvornice za preradu srdele koje su zapošljavale na tisuće radnika. Samo u Komiži na otoku Visu bilo ih je šest. Danas prazne, u mjestima koja polako odumiru, sve te tvornice propadaju pod soli i hrđom. Soli onog istog mora koje je nekada davalo, a danas grmi: Eh da, ponizne sluge, sjetit ćete se dana, kada ste bili blagoslovljeni obiljem, a već sada plačete za štetom i nemarom koji prouzročiste svojim nepoštovanjem prema meni!
Kao što je nestala vreva u tvornicama srdela i radnički žar, tako je i ta ista srdela početkom novog milenija nestala na nekoliko godina iz dubina Jadranskog mora, što je poprilično uplašilo sve one koji od mora i s morem žive. Očekivano, pojavilo se pitanje je li to početak kraja… ili ipak nije, već samo podsjetnik na to kako mnogim vrstama prijeti izumiranje. S nostalgijom, prisjetih se priča lastovskih ribara kako se nekada u vrijeme mrijesta jastoga moglo s obale promatrati na desetine njihovih ticala kako vire iz pličina kristalno čistog mora, što se danas smatra tek bujnom maštom. Danas su ovom jedinstvenom raku staništa gotovo uništena, zbog modernih načina lova pa, često, i nekontroliranog izlova. Ali nije jastog jedini ugrožen već i ostali junaci s ovih razglednica: kovač, škampi, trlje… Zar je moguće da je Lergetporer, poput Nostradamusa, predvidio da ćemo jednog dana umjesto odlaska na ribarnicu i uživanja u mediteranskom folkloru koji ona pruža, tek nositi ove ribe u uspomenama pa im je dao glavne uloge u svom kartofiličarskom igrokazu. Vjerujem da ne, motiv je bio isključivo stvaralački, a mi se nadajmo da će ljudska svijest na vrijeme proraditi i dati nam snage suočiti se s izazovima modernog doba i sačuvati mora i njihove faunu.
Stoga, neka glavni akteri ovih osam prikazanih razglednica ne ostanu samo puke uspomene već naša svakodnevica kao, uostalom, i svjetionici koji predstavljaju poseban dodatak vremenu kada se Jadranom plovilo bez suvremenih navigacijskih uređaja, a brodove su vrebale mnoge hridi, golom oku nevidljive.


Svjetlo reflektirano iz ovih kamenih titana spašavalo je živote, otvaralo puteve prema Italiji na sjeveru ili Mediteranu na jugu, učinilo Jadran sigurnim za plovidbu. S izgradnjom se započelo već u 19. stoljeću, kada se svjetionici grade uz prirodne plovne puteve. Prvi se dovršava na rtu Savudrija 1818. Uz njegov nastanak veže se priča dostojna najvećih ljubavnih drama. Naime, ugledni austrijski političar je upoznao mladu Hrvaticu tijekom jednog bala na bečkom dvoru. Količina emocija i simpatija koje su ga obuzele brzo su ga vratile u mladost i, nakon što ju je osvojio, zaljubljeni nesretnik je počeo razmišljati o tome kako bi mogli provoditi vrijeme zajedno, a da ne ugrozi svoj društveni status i brak. Na njen nagovor doputovao je u Istru i, ugledavši rt Savudrija, odmah se dosjetio da bi pod krinkom izgradnje svjetionika izoliranog daleko od pogleda znatiželjnika mogao dolaziti neometano i provoditi vrijeme sa svojom ljubavnicom. Nažalost, mlada dama nije uspjela doživjeti završetak izgradnje svjetionika, naglo se razboljela i umrla.. a savudrijski svjetionik bio je uvertira za izgradnju desetaka drugih širom Jadrana tijekom čitavog stoljeća.
Teško je reći jesu li i drugi nastajali pod sličnim krinkama ili gradeći neke svoje legende, ali je sigurno da se zbog dislociranosti uz svjetionike uvijek vežu neke mistične priče koje ih redovito časte atributima nepoznati, tajanstveni, nestvarni…. Stoga, nije ni čudno što se svjetioničari, na ono malo svjetionika koji nisu postali automatizirani pa i danas imaju ljudsku posadu, karakteriziraju kao samotnjaci i čudaci, iako samo možemo biti ljubomorni na život koji one vode, daleko od modernih gradskih mravinjaka, gdje nam užurbani ritam življenja ne dozvoljava vratiti se istinskim korijenima. Znaju oni s kolikim veseljem se vraćaju na svjetionik nakon kratkotrajnog boravka u grotlu civilizacije. A mi, kako li tek griješimo u svojim uvjerenjima jer, uistinu, postoji li nešto ljepše od onog kada se budiš uz šum valova i miris mora remećen tek ponekim krikom galebova, a toneš u san na modrim zrakama sreće i spokoja?
Dislociranost je i doprinijela tome da su svjetionike rijetko posjećivali fotografi u želji da ih snime i tiskaju kao klasične razglednice.Stoga danas i djeluju tako egzotično na starim razglednicama. Oni na sjevernom Jadranu manje su rijetki, iako ni to nije pravilo, dok je u čitavoj Dalmaciji poznato tek nekoliko razglednica svjetionika i to s motivima Velog Rata, Palagruže, Mula kod Rogoznice i Pokonjeg dola kod Hvara, iako ih je izgrađeno daleko više.
Situaciju donekle popravljaju foto-razglednice koje nam otkrivaju neke ratne događaje poput višekratne kanonade austrijske mornarice po ljepotici Palagruži 1915. Zahvaljujući vojnom fotografu s austrijskih torpednih brodova, danas o ovom događaju svjedoči serija od nekoliko razglednica, koje uključuju bombardiranje otoka, kao i završni čin – ruševine ovog monumentalnog zdanja. Ratna propaganda bila je vrlo aktivna u veličanju uspjeha, pa su ovakve razglednice često slali vojnici svojim obiteljima, kako bi im dočarali svoje vojničke ratne avanture. Svjetionik Palagruža obnovljen je po završetku Prvog svjetskog rata. Svakako, zanimljiv je i podatak da je srušeni svjetionik bio poznat po najsnažnijem svjetlu, koje je bilo vidljivo na čak 26 nautičkih milja. Najstariji svjetionik izgrađen u Dalmaciji daleke 1849. je Veli Rat na Dugom otoku i ima najviši toranj među svim jadranskim svjetionicima. Poznat je po tome da je za izradu njegovog pročelja potrošeno čak 100 000 žumanjaka. Mulo kod Rogoznice prvi je 1898. fotografirao Ante Vlahović, šibenski fotoamater, koji je Rogoznicu često pohodio vikendom dolazeći u posjet svom ujaku župniku. Upravo ta, i još nekoliko, fotografija Vlahovića objavljene su kao prva serija razglednica Rogoznice 1899. pa je Mulo ponio titulu prvog dalmatinskog svjetionika na razglednici. Danas se zna za samo četiri sačuvana primjerka pomno čuvana u privatnim zbirkama u Rogoznici, Splitu, Zagrebu i Veneciji. Ona je femme fatale, nedosanjani san mnogih sakupljača.
Fotografi su svjetionike najčešće snimali tako da se vide monumentalni tornjevi i zgrade, stoga posebno raduje sasvim atipična razglednica svjetionika na otoku Susku iz 1899. Prikazuje ulaz u samu zgradu s natpisom PHARUS SANSEGO …, a svjetioničarska obitelj, uzbuđena zbog dolaska gostiju, ne može sakriti osmijeh sa svojih lica. Čitavu zgodu pozdravlja i pjev grdelina iz krletki obješenih pokraj vrata kojim kao da žele održati koncert pred nikad većim auditorijem. U pitanju je i vrlo rijedak primjer koji svjedoči o životu na svjetionicima u 19. stoljeću.
Svaka od ovih malobrojnih razglednica krije neku priču o sebi. One su, svakako, važan prilog pomorskoj kulturi hrvatskog Jadrana i navode na razmišljanje. Danas se postavlja bespotrebno i bespredmetno pitanje jesu li svi ti svjetionici koje je gradila Austro-Ugarska Monarhija diljem jadranske obale tijekom 19. stoljeća narušili prirodnu harmoniju i mir na svim tim hridinama i rtovima. Sada, kada se podiže ekološka svijest, kao da se zaboravlja koliko brodoloma je izbjegnuto, a života spašeno zahvaljujući ovim kamenim čuvarima, razasutim između 1244 otoka, otočića, hridi i grebena hrvatskog Jadrana. Pred nama je imperativ da svakog od njih, kao najkrhkiju čipku u škrinji dotarice, njegujemo i čuvamo, kako njihov sjaj nikad ne bi izblijedio. Globalna slava koju o njima prenose tisuće turista koji ih svaku godinu pohode svakako će u tome doprinijeti. Koliko li samo posebnosti kriju ovi biseri kada je netko spreman preletjeti pola svijeta da bi tu proveo najvažnije dane u godini, dane kada u meditativnom okruženju treba obnoviti svaki atom svoje energije i regenerirati se od nakupljenog stresa. Jesmo li MI uistinu svjesni ljepote kojom smo okruženi?


Preostaje nam samo čuvati ono što smo naslijedili, u čemu, svakako, pomaže i svijest o postojanju ovakvih razglednica. Mi kolekcionari, i dalje ćemo tragati za njima, duboko zadubljeni u vrtloge najegzotičnijih razgovora, zamišljajući kako nam se jednog dana ukazuju i razglednice s motivima srdela i jastoga, svjetionika na Sušcu ili Blitvenici, Grujici ili Prišnjaku? Hoće li se sakupljački snovi ostvariti, a ribe i lanterne Jadrana opstati – vrijeme će pokazati. Poželimo i njima i nama sreću!

Igor Goleš

The sea Battle of Vis took place on 20th July 1866 in the Adriatic Sea, near the island of Vis. The Habsburg Monarchy and the Kingdom of Italy confronted during this battle.

The Habsburg navy won the battle, which was a part of the Austro-Prussian war. In this war conflict the Kingdom of Italy was the Prussia’s ally. It was in Italia’s interest to conquer the ex Venetians’ estates on the east Adriatic coast which became a part of the Habsburg Monarchy after the peace agreement in Campo Formio in 1797.

This was the first great battle in which both armored ships and steamships took part. Also, that was the first battle in the history of the world in which two armored fleets confronted in the open sea. On the other hand, it was one of the last, if not the last, battles in which deliberate ramming was used. That tactic dates back from the time of Illyrians, in the early Middle Ages.

The Austrian fleet was led by Wilhelm von Tegetthoff, while the Italian fleet was led by count Carlo di Persano.

Since on the Austrian side there were numerous Croatian sailors (out of 7.871 sailors there were some 5000 Croatians), one of the most important consequences of the Vis victory was refuting the partiality for Italy and waking of the Croatian national awareness in Dalmatia.

The goal of the Italian war navy was achieving supremacy over the Adriatic, which could be seen in the instructions which the Italian government gave to the admiral Persano on 5th June 1866. In July the decision was made to occupy the island of Vis. On July 16th the Italian fleet of 28 warships set sails from Ancona, led by the admiral Persano, rear admiral Vaccao and vice admiral Albini. A day later Persano sent the scout ship “Messaggero” under the British flag all the way to Vis so that he would determine which places were the best ones to disembark the troupes.

The attack on the fortifications of Komiža and Vis began on 18th July, but the Italian fleet was not too successful, because the fortifications were situated too high above the sea. After that the inland fortifications of the Vis harbor and the Fort Georg were attacked and suffered considerable damages. During the day the Komiža and Vis fortifications were violently bombed, but due to their fierce resistance Persano and his officers didn’t dare to disembark the soldiers on the island.

On 20th July the Italian fleet suspended the attacks on the island and lined up in the formation expecting the arrival of the Austrian navy.

The Austrian headquarters were aware that the Italian ships were faster and better armed, so they decided to avoid the artillery fire and approach as soon as possible the Italian fleet, so that they could ram the enemy ships. The Austrian fleet had 27 ships, 57.433 tones of displacement, 532 cannons and 7.871 people, while the Italian fleet had 34 ships with 86.000 tons of displacement, 645 cannons and 10.886 people.

The Austrian admiral Tegethoff decided to gain advantage by attacking the Italian ships in a wedge formation making a turmoil in which the ships tried to ram each other. His ship, “SMS Erzherzog Ferdinand Max”, ran into the middle of the flank of the Italian ship “Re d’Italia” which sank in three minutes together with 400 crew members. When the Italian ship “Palestro” exploded around 2.30 PM, Persano ordered back up, even though he still outnumbered the Austrian fleet. The two Italian ironclads, “Palestro” and “Re d’Italia”, were entirely destroyed, while on the Austrian side the unarmored ship “Kaiser” was the one which suffered the most damage. Even though they were outnumbered and weaker, the Austrian navy achieved a great and crucial victory, while the Italian navy failed to achieve predominance over Adriatic due to the Vis failure.

Pomorska bitka kod Visa zbila se 20. srpnja 1866. godine u Jadranskom moru, u blizini otoka Visa . U njoj su se sukobile mornarice Habsburške Monarhije i Kraljevine Italije.

Bitka je završila pobjedom habsburške mornarice, a bila je dijelom austro-pruskog rata. U tom ratnom sukobu Kraljevina Italija bila je saveznica Pruske. Talijanski interes je bio zauzimanje bivših mletačkih posjeda na istočnojadranskoj obali koji su mirom u Campo Formiju 1797. godine pripali Habsburškoj Monarhiji.

 

Ovo je bila prva velika pomorska bitka u kojoj su sudjelovali oklopljeni brodovi i brodovi na parni pogon. Također, to je i prva bitka u svjetskoj povijesti u kojoj su se dvije oklopljene flote sukobile na otvorenom moru. Jednako tako, bila je jedna od zadnjih, ako ne i zadnja bitka, koja je koristila probijanje broda kljunom kao ratnu taktiku, tehniku koja se koristila još u doba Ilira, u ranom starom vijeku.

Austrijsku flotu predvodio je Wilhelm von Tegetthoff, dok je zapovjednik talijanske flote bio grof Carlo di Persano.

Budući da su na austrijskoj strani sudjelovali brojni hrvatski mornari (od 7.871 mornara bilo je oko 5.000 Hrvata), važna posljedica austrijske pobjede pod Visom bilo je odbacivanje naklonosti prema Italiji i buđenje hrvatske nacionalne svijesti u Dalmaciji.

Cilj talijanske ratne mornarice bio je ostvarivanje prevlasti nad Jadranom, što je vidljivo iz instrukcija koje je 5. lipnja 1866. talijanska vlada dala admiralu Persanu. U srpnju je donesena odluka da se zauzme otok Vis. Dana 16. srpnja isplovila je talijanska flota od 28 ratnih brodova iz Ancone na čelu s admiralom Persanom te kontraadmiralom Vaccaom i viceadmiralom Albinijem. Dan kasnije, Persano je poslao izviđački brod “Messaggero” pod britanskom zastavom do Visa kako bi ustanovio koja su mjesta najbolja za iskrcavanje trupa.

Napad na utvrđenja Komiže i Visa započeo je 18. srpnja, ali talijanska flota u početku nije bila odviše uspješna, jer su utvrđenja bila smještena previsoko nad morem. Nakon toga, napadnuta su unutrašnja utvrđenja viške luke i tvrđava Georg koje su pretrpjela znatne štete.  Tijekom dana nastavljena su silovita bombardiranja komiških i viških utvrđenja, ali zbog njihova žestoka otpora Persano i njegovi časnici nisu se usuđivali izvršiti iskrcaj vojnika na otok.

Dana 20. srpnja talijanska flota je obustavila napade na otok i postrojila se u formaciju očekujući dolazak austrijske mornarice.

Austrijsko zapovjedništvo bilo je svjesno da je talijansko brodovlje brže i bolje naoružano, pa su odlučili nastojati izbjeći artiljerijsku vatru i čim prije približiti se talijanskoj floti, kako bi neprijateljske brodove napali kljunovima. Austrijska flota brojila je 27 brodova, 57.344 t deplasmana, 532 topa i 7.871 ljudi, a talijanska 34 broda sa 86.000 t deplasmana, 645 topa i 10.886 ljudi.

Austrijski admiral Tegetthoff odlučio je ostvariti prednost tako što je napao talijansko brodovlje u klinastoj formaciji i stvorio metež u kojem su brodovi nastojali jedan drugoga probosti kljunom. Njegov brod “SMS Erzherzog Ferdinand Max” zaletio se usred boka talijanskom brodu “Re d’Italia” koji je potonuo za tri minuta zajedno s 400 članova posade. Kad je oko 14.30 eksplodirao talijanski brod “Palestro”, Persano je naredio povlačenje, iako je i dalje bio brojačano superiorniji u odnosu na austrijsku flotu.Dvije talijanske oklopnjače, “Palestro” i “Re d’Italia”, u potpunosti su uništene, dok je na austrijskoj strani najteže stradao neoklopljeni brod “Kaiser”. Iako malobrojnija i slabije opremljena, austrijska mornarica je izvojevala veliku i presudnu pobjedu, dok je talijanska neuspjehom kod Visa propustila ostvariti prevlast nad Jadranom.

The bell tower of the Church of St. John and Paul in Ložišća is one of the most beautiful in Dalmatia, and older generations remember it for showing up in the opening credits of a cult Dalmatian serial Malo Misto (meaning: small town). There are two reasons for this: its beauty, but also a sign of appreciation of the Malo Misto screenwriter Miljenko Smoje to the Ložišća mailman Frane Pavlov, for his chronics of this small town, in which he noted everything that was going on here for decades. Smoje himself must have found some inspiration for his texts in these chronics, just like in the beauty of this town itself. And why wouldn’t he? Have you had the opportunity to visit Brač and see Ložišća? Some kind of Dalmatia it is! It is untouched and authentic, like the one from the end of the 19th century.

While passing through Ložišća one simply must stop and take in some of this clearest beauty and enjoy the view of the bell tower itself.

There is an interesting story on how such a small village got such an impressive bell tower, built by drawings of Ivan Rendić, a famous sculptor.

Frane Pavlov wrote in his memoires about this event. The villagers contacted at that time a great sculptor Rendić and asked him to make them offer for a bell tower. Rendić sent them two drawings of common village bell towers, but also a more luxurious one, wanting to make fun of them, knowing that they could not afford such a bell tower. The pastor hung all of the three drafts on the church door so that the decision would be on the people. And the people unanimously chose the third one – the prettiest and the most expensive one. There was no money for that project, so they asked for a loan from the wealthiest local, Mihovil Nazor, MD. He had just returned to his village to enjoy his retirement, after having worked for years in Pula, where he was the principal doctor for the Harbor admiralty and at the same time the liable doctor of the Pula Navy hospital. During the time he served the Austrian war navy, this man from Ložišća used to be also the personal doctor for Maximilian Habsburg, the archduke of Austria.

He agreed to lend the villagers the money, but only if they returned it – in wine, even though he never really counted on them returning it. Every villager was supposed to give him a barrel of wine every year in order for the debt to be paid off, which they in the end did, all the way to the beginning of the World War One. The bell tower itself was built from 1884 to 1889. The first contractor who was chosen to do the job was Šare from Split, but he soon gave up on such a complicated undertaking. After that, a young stonemason Matzenik offered to take the job – he came from somewhere outside Zadar to work at the local quarry and married a girl from Ložišća. The people of Ložišća had no other or better solution, so they accepted his offer, doubting him greatly. Matzenik did not sleep for days or nights, studying every stone so that he would place it just as Rendić planned. And in the end he succeeded. The bell tower was built, and the debt was in time paid off.

This is a proof that one should believe in their dreams, never give up, and contemporary generations from this small village are proud of the beauty of this recognizable bell tower.

 

Igor Goleš

Zvonik crkve svetog Ivana i Pavla u Ložišćima jedan je od najljepših u Dalmaciji, a poznat je  starijim generacijama i po tome što se pojavljuje u uvodnoj špici kultne dalmatinske  serije  Malo Misto. Dva su razloga za to; njegova ljepota , ali i zahvala scenariste Malog mista Miljenka Smoje ložišćkom poštaru Frani Pavlovu za njegove kronike ovog Malog mista  kojima je bilježio sve ono što se tu dešavalo kroz desetljeća  . Zasigurno je i sam Smoje u njima pronašao inspiraciju za svoje tekstove, ali i u samoj ljepoti ovog malog mista. A i  i kako ne bi ? Jeste li imali priliku doći na Brač i vidjeti  Ložišća ?  Kakva je to samo Dalmacija, netaknuta i upravo autentična, ona s kraja 19.stoljeća.

Prolazivši kroz Ložišća ne možete ne stati i napiti se  ove najbistrije ljepote i uživati u pogledu na  sam zvoniku.

Zanimljiva je priča o  tome kako je tako malo selo dobilo takav impresivan zvonik , rađen po nacrtima čuvenog kipara Ivana Rendića.

Poznata je zgoda o kojoj je pisao u svojim memoarima Frane Pavlov kako je na upit seljana Rendić njima poslao dva nacrta zvonika običnih seoskih ali   i jedan raskošan,  kako bi se malo našalio s njima, znajući da oni ne mogu platiti izradu takvog zvonika. Župnik je sva tri nacrta izvjesio na crkvena vrata kako bi narod odlučio i  puk je jednoglasno odabrao onaj treći, najljepši i najskuplji. Novca za taj poduhvat nije bilo pa ga je posudio najbogatiji mještanin Ložišća, dr Mihovil Nazor, koji se vratio u selo uživati umirovljeničke dane , nakon višegodišnjeg rada u Puli  gdje je bio glavni liječnik u Lučkom admiralatu, i istodobno odgovorni liječnik pulske Mornaričke bolnice. Za vrijeme službe u austrijskoj ratnoj mornarici ovaj ložišćanin  je bio  i osobni liječnik  princa nadvojvode Maksimilijana Habsburga.

Njegov jedini uvjet  da bi seljacima pozajmio novac je bio da mu dug odrade vrate u vinu, ali uglavnom i nije  računao na njegovo vraćanje. Svaki je bratim trebao godišnje davati baril vina za vraćanje duga, i to se protezalo sve do prvoga svjetskog rata. Zvonik se gradio od 1884 sve do 1889.  Prvi građevni poduzetnik odabran za posao bio je Šare iz Splita, ali je ubrzo odustao od tako kompliciranog pothvata.  Ponudio se za izgradnju potom mladi klesar Matzenik iz okolice Zadra, koji je radio u obližnjem kamenolomu i oženio se djevojkom iz Ložišća. Ložišćani, s velikom sumnjom u njegovu nedovoljnu stručnost, u nedostatku boljeg rješenja , ipak su  pristali . Ne spavajući ni danju ni noću, proučavao je Matzenik svaki kamen da bi  ga ugradio prema Rendićevom nacrtu. I uspio je naposljetku. Zvonik je sagrađen, a dug  s vremenom plaćen.

Dokaz kako u svoje snove treba vjerovati, i nikada ne odustajati, na ponos današnjih generacija iz ovog malog mista.

Igor Goleš
